text: My recipe book is 10% instructions, 90% sauce stains.
Every meal I cook starts with ‘what do I have?’ and ends with ‘nailed it?’
Cooking is jazz. Baking is math. I failed math.
Some people meditate. I aggressively whisk pancake batter.
I like my meals like my memes: quick, hot, and shared too much.
What’s for dinner? A complicated question with an emotional answer.
No one warns you adulting includes deciding what to cook every day forever.
Dinner party tip: serve cheese first so people forgive your cooking.
I don’t bake often because my oven has commitment issues.
Fridge check: 3 sauces, 1 tomato, endless possibilities.
Real chefs taste constantly. I taste aggressively.
Eating your mistakes is part of the culinary journey.
I followed the recipe exactly and still ended up with soup pizza.
The kitchen is my chaotic safe space.
If loving carbs is wrong, I don’t want to be right.
Recipe idea: toast. But fancy. But not really. Just toast.
Sometimes dinner is a success. Sometimes it’s cereal.
I treat my spice rack like a personality test.
Nothing says 'I’m thriving' like homemade soup and clean counters.
A little burnt? Call it flavor depth.
I don’t count calories. I count garlic cloves.
Sometimes the best seasoning is confidence.
My measuring spoon is a guess and a prayer.
There’s always room for dessert. Especially if it’s yours.
Meal plan? More like meal improv.
Dinner in 30 minutes or your panic back.
Add cheese until you feel something.
Cooking is when your soul speaks through steam.
Pasta doesn’t ask questions. Pasta understands.
Garlic bread is proof there’s good in the world.
My kitchen, my rules, my smoke alarm.
I trust no one who says ‘too much garlic’.
Cooking tip: pretend the recipe is a suggestion, then add butter.
Salt is magic. So is a clean pan.
Meal prep is a love letter to future me.
Kitchen rule #1: clean as you go. Kitchen reality: don’t.
I don’t use timers. I use vibes and regrets.
The only thing rising in my kitchen is my stress and maybe the dough.
My favorite dish? Whatever doesn’t stick to the pan.
Real chefs cry when they run out of olive oil.
The more effort I put in, the more likely I’ll just eat snacks instead.
No matter how big the kitchen, I always cook in one tiny corner.
Dinner doesn’t have to be perfect. It just has to be done.
If I could sauté my problems, I would.
Why yes, that is a recipe I made up and will never recreate again.
My food pyramid is mostly pasta and denial.
If you can't stand the heat, eat ice cream.
Cooking when hungry is an Olympic sport.
Half the time I cook just to use that one pan I like.
No one told me growing up meant making dinner every night forever.
Cooking is my love language. Cleaning up is not.
Every great dish starts with too much garlic.
I don’t meal prep. I meal guess.
The fridge light is my midnight spotlight.
Baking is chemistry. Cooking is chaos. I like both.
If it says 'let it rest,' I do too.
Why yes, I do cry when cutting onions and when I burn dinner.
Oil, salt, garlic. That’s the holy trinity.
There’s no such thing as too much cheese. Only not enough.
Cooking rule: taste it, adjust, taste again. Repeat until full.
I put 'chef' in my bio because I didn’t burn breakfast today.
Every recipe is a journey. Some get lost. Some arrive deliciously.
Leftovers are tomorrow’s miracle or mystery.
Cooking mistake? Turn off the lights and serve it anyway.
Food so good, even the smoke alarm wants a taste.
I measure garlic with my heart. And by heart, I mean a lot.
Some days you sous-vide. Some days you microwave. Balance.
A kitchen without mess is a kitchen without flavor.
Soup is just an excuse to throw everything in one pot.
People count sheep. I count pasta boiling.
I didn’t burn dinner. I added personality.
My cutting board has more knife marks than my heart has scars.
Cooking is therapy you can eat.
If it’s not sizzling, it’s not exciting.
Salting pasta water is non-negotiable. Like rent.
I came, I cooked, I overestimated how hungry I was.
Some cookbooks are just confidence boosters for freestylers like me.
The more garlic, the closer to greatness.
Whisking aggressively fixes most problems.
Recipes lie. Add more seasoning anyway.
I season food like I argue online: passionately and without mercy.
Burnt edges? That’s flavor. Trust me.
Cooking at home means snacks before, during, and after dinner.
The kitchen is my gym. I lift cast iron skillets daily.
Pouring olive oil is an emotional decision.
My favorite utensil? The one that’s clean.
I don’t need a timer. I need discipline.
Kitchen success is 10% recipe, 90% attitude.
I treat my spices like friends: the more, the better.
If it sticks to the pan, it's rustic.
My apron has more sauce stains than a mafia movie.
Kitchen playlist: clanging pots and internal screaming.
A good stew takes time. And patience. And maybe a glass of wine.
Microwaves are fine. Just don’t tell the food snobs.
Real talk: cooking is 70% cleaning up after yourself.
Some call it leftovers. I call it pre-cooked perfection.
Breakfast for dinner is always a good idea.
